text: Hi guys, just joined this group.  Happy to be here.  I work in a B2B company that has been old-school for a long time.  We are located in 80 countries so we have a lot of hurdles to figure out what content works where and whether written, audio, or video is the best play for us.  Do any of you have tips on helping an organization pivot into new means of marketing and prospecting knowing that we may not see many quick results while we work out the initial bumps in the road?  Any tips would be helpful!

elements.text: Hi guys, just joined this group.  Happy to be here.  I work in a B2B company that has been old-school for a long time.  We are located in 80 countries so we have a lot of hurdles to figure out what content works where and whether written, audio, or video is the best play for us.  Do any of you have tips on helping an organization pivot into new means of marketing and prospecting knowing that we may not see many quick results while we work out the initial bumps in the road?  Any tips would be helpful!

text:
I’ve been helping a B2B company in an old school industry (manufacturing) for a couple of months now, here are my thoughts:

• Make sure it’s an initiative that top executives are 100% behind. You don’t want anyone directly/indirectly undermining your work. You’re going to need all the support you can get.
• Start small – no one in my client’s industry did any real content marketing so small things like having a good website, a regular content schedule etc. actually made a lot of noise. So don’t think you need to do a lot, all at once. Get the basics covered and slowly build up (especially if you’re a super large organization).
• Sync with the sales team. Animalz has a really good article on this actually. 
• Enhance whatever existing marketing there is – I think the impulse when you’re doing new marketing initiatives is to just brainstorm 100% new things. But there’s a lot to gain from just using different, digital tactics to boost what’s already there (e.g. industry events).

elements.text: I’ve been helping a B2B company in an old school industry (manufacturing) for a couple of months now, here are my thoughts:
Make sure it’s an initiative that top executives are 100% behind. You don’t want anyone directly/indirectly undermining your work. You’re going to need all the support you can get.

Start small – no one in my client’s industry did any real content marketing so small things like having a good website, a regular content schedule etc. actually made a lot of noise. So don’t think you need to do a lot, all at once. Get the basics covered and slowly build up (especially if you’re a super large organization).
Sync with the sales team. Animalz has a really good article on this actually.

Enhance whatever existing marketing there is – I think the impulse when you’re doing new marketing initiatives is to just brainstorm 100% new things. But there’s a lot to gain from just using different, digital tactics to boost what’s already there (e.g. industry events).

text:
The beauty of working for an established company is that your company likely has a very solid idea of who your customer is, so take advantage of that.

Elaborating on what <@UUVC9HJTE> said, sync with your sales and leadership teams to build some solid customer personas. At first, at least anecdotally, you should be able to come up with some pretty solid guesses as to what content channels will appeal most to them and be most effective.

You can also survey your clients as to what they would like to see from you.

Then it's just about trying different avenues and seeing what works, using data to back your strategy choice as much as you can, not being afraid to hop around as needed.

It is harder to be nimble in 80 countries, but try testing out a few strategies in one or two representative markets first.
